texts.en:
Mwero is married with twelve children, five of whom attend school while seven graduated from school. He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, he has operated a retail shop business, selling to his neighbours and passersby. He faces a major challenge of competition from other retail operators in her business. He dreams of expanding his business to meet his customers' needs.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past the four years, she has operated a meat goat selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of theft of livestock in her business. Elizabeth dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers' needs.

With the loan, she wants to purchase a cow to sell for meat. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a cow to sell for meat.

loans.name: Nyamvula

texts.en:
Nyamvula is a widow with two children, both of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that neither has electricity and nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers' needs.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Nzadze

texts.en:
Nzadze is a married woman with four children; one attends school while three are still too young for school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past one year, she has operated a kiosk business, selling in this shop to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of delayed payments by creditors. She dreams of expanding to a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase maize flour, wheat flour and sugar for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, wheat flour and sugar for sale.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a married woman with five children, three of whom attend school while two are still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past one year, Salome has operated a grocery business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge with delayed payments from those who purchase goods on credit. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customer demand. 

With the Kshs 20,000 loan she wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes, cabbages and green vegetables. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes, cabbages and green vegetables.

loans.name: Abu-Bakarr

texts.en:
This is 29-year-old Abu-Bakarr. He is married and has one child. In 2007, Abu-Bakarr established his games and sport business. He began his business because he was not able to secure a job after graduating from school and needed a source of income for his livelihood. Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,300,000 every month from this business. 

Abu-Bakarr requires a loan in order to buy a new generator and electric fan, and to pay for his DSTV subscription. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. In the future, Abu-Bakarr plans to send his child to a very good university and build a dwelling house. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy a generator and electric fan, and to pay for his DSTV subscription.

loans.name: Wangoni

texts.en:
Wangoni is a married man with two children who are still too young for school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and medical bills.

For the past two years, he has operated a clothes selling business, selling door to door to his neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge of delayed payments from those who purchase goods on credit. Wangoni dreams of expanding his business and establishing a retail shop business in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 he wants to purchase bundles of clothes for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Nyamawi

texts.en:
Nyamawi is a married man with seven children. Five attend school while two are still too young for school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past two years, he has operated a business selling goat meat. He sells at the market to his neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge of delayed payments from those who purchase goods on credit.

With the Kshs 15,000 he wants to purchase goats to sell for meat. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase goats to sell for meat.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 34 and a married woman with four children, three of whom still attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, Maraaret has operated a retail shop, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge with the seasonality of her business. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers' needs and to hire more employees. 

With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and salt. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and salt.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
This is 43-year-old Alice.  She is married and has three children aged 29, 23 and 9. She has one additional dependent who lives with her because of schooling.  

In 2007, Alice established her provision, drinks and toiletries business. She never went to school and her mother trained her to do business, so when she was grown up she started her own business. This business is a source of livelihood for Alice and her family. Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she earns about Le 1,600,000 every month.

Alice requires a loan in order to buy sardines, mayonnaise, milk, sugar, drinks and toiletries for her business. Alice would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. In the future, Alice plans to build a house and support the University for All Her Children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy sardines, mayonnaise, milk, sugar, drinks and toiletries for her business.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is 45 and married with three children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food and school fees.

For the past four years, Monica has operated a retail shop, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge with the seasonality of her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and tea leaves. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and tea leaves.

loans.name: Mumbua

texts.en:
Mumbua is 65 and a married woman with two children, all of whom are grown ups. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge with the seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase shop items such as bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and tea leaves. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase shop items such as bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and tea leaves.
